风景摄影：综合指南（+ 23 个专家提示）首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

大多数人没有意识到这一点，但捕捉广阔的远景或山脉的美丽图像并不是一件容易的事。风景摄影不仅仅是将相机对准美丽的物体并按下快门。这与技术、正确的装备以及了解如何充分利用您的设置有关。

幸运的是，只要掌握正确的提示、技巧和技巧，即使是初学者也能拍摄出令人惊叹的风景照片。这就是我在这篇文章中分享的内容：您想了解的有关风景摄影的所有内容，包括实际上保证为您拍摄出精彩照片的技术，无论您的经验水平如何。

继续阅读以发现：

  • 拍摄风景照的必备装备
  • 最好的风景摄影照明（以及您应该不惜一切代价避免的光线类型）
  • 完美的风景摄影设置
  • 专业人士使用的景观构图秘诀
  • 让你的风景照片变得独一无二的简单技巧
  • 多得多！

我还提供了大量示例照片；这样，您就可以看到实际的提示（并且您可以确信它们确实有效！）。

让我们开始吧。

最好的风景摄影装备

您可能认为您可以使用智能手机拍摄一些照片，您并非完全错误。智能手机已经取得了长足的进步，它们的相机可以拍出一些精彩的照片。但是，假设您想要更多 - 更多控制、更多细节，以及创建能够准确反映您正在捕捉的场景的大照片的能力。这就是专业风景摄影设备发挥作用的地方。投资合适的装备可以让你的摄影效果从“还好”变成“令人惊叹”。

可互换镜头相机

如果您认真对待风景类型，您会想要选择一台好的风景摄影相机，例如全画幅数码单反相机或无反光镜型号。例如，佳能 EOS R5或 索尼 a7R IV将提供大量的百万像素（用于制作大型照片）以及稳定的低光功能（用于天文摄影）。如果您的预算紧张，请考虑较旧的全画幅 DSLR（例如佳能 6D或尼康 D800 ）。请记住，传感器越大越好，但传感器较小的 APS-C 或微型三分之四相机肯定可以完成任务。

广角镜头

一旦您获得了一台好的相机，您就会想要拥有一些高质量的风景摄影镜头。广角镜头是一个很好的起点。广角镜头的美妙之处在于它可以捕捉到更多您面前的场景。如果您最初只能买一个镜头，我通常建议使用广角到标准变焦镜头。对于那些刚刚开始摄影之旅的人来说，24-70mm f/4 镜头是一个不错的选择。

然而，不要只使用一个镜头就太舒服了。随着时间的推移，你会想要多元化。例如，70-200mm f/4 镜头可让您在不牺牲质量的情况下捕捉更亲密的风景场景。如果您正在寻找能够捕捉广阔远景的镜头，超广角 12-24mm f/4 镜头是完美的选择，尽管它可能有点贵。

三脚架

虽然我稍后会详细讨论相机设置，但重要的是要认识到大多数风景摄影都是在狭窄的光圈和光线较低的情况下进行的。当然可以实现曝光良好的照片，但通常只有将快门速度延长到 1/30 秒及以上才能实现。

如果你曾经尝试过以 1/30 秒的速度手持相机，你就会知道这真的很难；除非你的手非常稳定并且你的技术非常出色，否则你最终会得到无法使用的模糊图像。 （此外，即使是最稳定的摄影师也经常无法以一秒或更高的快门速度手持图像！）

这就是一个好的风景三脚架派上用场的地方。您可以使用它来稳定您的相机，并在 1 秒、5 秒甚至 30 秒的长时间曝光下保持照片清晰。是的，三脚架可能很昂贵，但最好的三脚架可以使用多年。将其视为对照片清晰度的投资！

顺便说一句：即使光线足够强，可以提供较快的快门速度，三脚架仍然很有用。它会迫使你放慢速度并更仔细地考虑你的构图。

一些过滤器

初学者常常忽视过滤器的重要性。在捕捉完美镜头的兴奋中，您很容易忘记有时您需要额外装备的帮助。圆偏振镜就是这样一种可以改变游戏规则的滤镜。当您拍摄水体时，它可以减少不必要的反射，并使秋季森林照片中的色彩更加流行。因此，它是您装备中的必备品。

中性密度 (ND) 滤镜是另一套非常有用的工具。这些滤镜减少了进入镜头的光线量，让您可以使用更长的快门速度。结果？无论是丝般光滑的水面还是纤细的云朵，都能拍出令人惊叹的长时间曝光照片。您可能还听说过分级中性密度滤光片。它们可能有用，但不是必需的；您可以使用高动态范围 (HDR) 技术实现类似的效果。

关键配件

装备不仅仅停留在相机和镜头上。如果您徒步穿越大自然寻找独一无二的镜头，您将需要一些额外的东西来让您的生活更轻松。舒适、宽敞的背包是您的首要必备品。相信我，当您徒步数小时寻找完美地点时，一切都会变得不同。

不要忘记额外的电池。想象一下天空变成了那些神奇的暮光色彩，而你的相机却快要死了——令人心碎。携带的电池数量一定要多于您认为需要的数量。存储卡也是如此；您不想在光线变得完美时就用完存储空间。

当我们谈论存储时，外部硬盘驱动器可以让您高枕无忧。那些美丽的风景，你辛苦了；无论发生什么情况，为他们提供支持都可以确保他们的安全。

风景摄影的最佳相机设置

当您在野外时，相机设置可以决定您的风景照片的成败。实现令人惊叹的拍摄不仅仅需要在正确的时间出现在正确的地点；还需要在正确的时间进行正确的拍摄。仔细调整设置以获得您预期的结果也很重要。这是我的建议：

以手动模式拍摄

如果您想创作既具有艺术​​感又充满细节的风景照片，那么我强烈建议您学习使用相机的手动模式设置。

您会看到，手动模式可让您独立处理三个曝光变量，每个变量对图像的影响不同：

  • 光圈可以使图像变亮或变暗，还可以增加或减少景深（即聚焦的图像量）。
  • 快门速度可以让您使图像变亮或变暗，还可以让您增加或减少图像中存在的运动模糊量
  • ISO可让您使图像变亮或变暗，但 ISO 越高，文件中出现的噪点（破坏细节的光线和颜色斑点）就越多

虽然我在下面更详细地讨论我的风景摄影设置建议，但重要的是要认识到，通过完全控制相机，您可以调整图像曝光，增加景深，防止噪点，并在以下位置添加艺术运动模糊效果：会。

虽然您始终可以使用光圈优先等半自动模式来拍摄风景，但根据我的经验，最好直接负责并处理您的设置！

使用窄光圈以获得最大景深

在风景摄影中，深景深几乎总是最佳选择。换句话说，您应该尽量让场景保持清晰。

为什么？从前到后清晰的风景提供了各种美丽的细节供眼睛探索 - 而且感觉更真实，就像观看者可以向前迈进并直接陷入场景中一样。

现在，最大化景深的最简单方法是选择小光圈设置（即大 f 值，例如 f/11 或 f/16）。光圈越小，景深越大，风景就越清晰。

选择较慢的快门速度和较低的 ISO

如果您曾因风景曝光不足而感到沮丧，那么您并不孤单。狭窄的光圈将为您提供所需的景深，但它也会减少到达相机传感器的光线，并阻止您的照片呈现出您所追求的清晰细节。

因此，请确保将窄光圈与慢快门速度配对。较慢的快门速度，尤其是 1/60 秒或更慢的快门速度，可以让更多的光线照射到传感器上。这补偿了通过狭窄光圈的有限光线。

但请记住，慢速快门需要稳定的三脚架。除非您希望您的风景像一幅抽象画，否则保持相机静止是没有商量余地的！

现在我们来谈谈ISO。提高 ISO 可以使图像变亮，但它是一把双刃剑。高 ISO 会引入噪点，这种颗粒状纹理是图像质量的死敌。噪声不仅会破坏细节，还会扰乱动态范围。那么外卖呢？保持较低的 ISO，如果需要增加曝光，请调整快门速度。

风景摄影技巧

准备好学习如何将风景拍摄从零变成英雄了吗？在本节中，我将提供有关如何使用光线、创作令人惊叹的构图等等的最佳技巧。

1. 提前勘察潜在位置

把风景摄影想象成一顿精心准备的饭菜。侦察是您在实际烹饪开始之前所做的准备工作。相信我，捕捉千载难逢的镜头的关键通常涉及大量的准备工作，就像在厨房一样。侦察的重要性怎么强调都不为过。有时，你只要出现就可以得到幸运的机会，但大多数时候，神奇的事情发生是因为你知道在哪里以及何时出现。

首先在网上甚至通过老式地形图研究潜在的位置。只要有可能，请提前访问您选择的地点。这可能是在实际拍摄前几天、几周甚至几个小时。查看景观的几何形状，并想象不同的元素如何融入框架中。照明是另一个需要考虑的重要方面。显示太阳轨迹的应用程序可能是无价的工具。了解光线落在哪里可以帮助您预测拍摄对象在不同照明条件下的外观。因此，无论是著名的旅游景点还是国家公园的未开发角落，都请给自己充足的时间去探索。您的作品集将会因此而感谢您。

2.寻找焦点

一旦掌握了设置，就可以开始考虑风景摄影构图（即场景中元素的排列）。

虽然构图可能是一个复杂的主题，但我可以提供一些基本指南，这些指南将对您的照片产生巨大的影响。

首先，几乎每一张精彩的风景照片都需要某种焦点——一个吸引眼球并吸引观众注意力的主要主题。

根据我的经验，一张没有焦点的风景照片最终看起来相当平淡和空洞。另外，它会让观看者的眼睛在图像中徘徊，无处休息。

请注意，焦点可以采取多种形式，包括：

  • 建筑物和构筑物（如上图所示）
  • 引人注目的树木
  • 巨石或岩层
  • 野生动物剪影
  • 一个人

然后，一旦确定了风景照片的焦点，请仔细考虑将其放置在画面中的位置。尝试超越传统的“居中”构图（主要拍摄对象静态地坐在镜头中间）。相反，尝试使用三分法，或者通过将焦点放在一边来实现极简主义构图。

3.添加令人惊叹的前景

风景摄影师初学者往往会找到美丽的场景，对准相机，然后按下快门按钮。

虽然最终的镜头看起来不错，但它们常常缺少一些强大的东西：

引人注目的前景，能够立即吸引观众的注意力并帮助他们进入场景。 （好的前景还可以使场景显得更加立体，这几乎总是一件好事！）

好的前景往往具有美丽的细节，例如花朵、树叶、流过溪流的水、闪闪发光的岩石或拍打沙滩的波浪。例如，下一张图片使用了一片开满鲜花的田野来增加前景的趣味：

4.不要忘记天空

在风光摄影中，你应该永远、永远、永远思考天空。

例如，晴朗的天空往往看起来平淡而毫无生气，而云彩和阳光的混合则提供了各种有趣的东西（以及日出和日落时爆炸性的色彩！）。

我喜欢在计划风景摄影郊游之前查看天气预报；这样，我就可以在阴天出行，最大限度地享受美丽的天空。

现在，我并不是说您永远无法在晴朗的日子里拍摄出精美的风景照片。但是，如果您面对的是晴朗的天空，请考虑等待，看看是否有几朵云——或者，如果您没有时间，请尝试将天空放置在场景中，使天空从属于场景的其余部分。图像的上三分之一，并将其​​与令人惊叹的前景形成对比。

另一方面，如果天空充满戏剧性、有趣的云层或色彩，那就让它发光吧。将地平线放在画面的底部三分之一处以强调天空，如下所示：

专业提示：如果您的天空看起来没有您想要的那么强烈，请考虑使用滤镜增强它们。 中性密度滤镜可让您使用长快门速度，像棉花糖一样拉伸云层，而渐变中性密度滤镜将帮助您平衡天空和前景曝光，以便您可以捕捉大量细节。

5.简化你的作品

您是否曾经看过一张风景照片并感到不知所措？也许它充满了元素——树木、岩石、动物等等。但有时，少即是多。专注于最小的元素可以增强照片的视觉效果。

首先扫描您的场景。你能拿走什么？不断问这个问题，直到只剩下使场景变得特别的核心元素。

现在，考虑在构图时重点关注形状和线条，而不是实际的拍摄对象。一棵树变成了一条垂直线，一个湖变成了一个平面。这种抽象可以帮助您从几何角度看待场景，从而更轻松地构建引人注目的镜头。

剩下的就是几乎感觉像是现代艺术作品的风景照片。这种简单性吸引了观众，引导他们的眼睛毫不费力地浏览图像。相信我，这种技术将为您带来一些最难忘的捕捉。

6.使用引导线增添活力

引导线是引导眼睛浏览图像的线条（通常朝向主要主题；见上文！）。

在风景摄影中，一两条好的引导线可能是平庸的快照和出色的图像之间的区别。

（为什么？引导线将观众吸引到照片中，而且它们还增加了很多深度！）

现在，引导线似乎很难找到，但实际上很常见。你只需要知道去哪里找！例如，您可以使用以下方法创建引导线：

  • 道路
  • 砂纹
  • 退去的波浪
  • 河流
  • 冰上的裂缝
  • 树叶
  • 倒下的原木

事实上，任何类似线条的东西都可以工作。诀窍是将线条放置在前景中。然后使用广角镜头并降低角度，使画面中的引导线显得很大并立即吸引观看者：

7. 纳入人为因素以扩大规模

捕捉广阔的风景通常是一个真正的挑战。很多时候，一张照片无法传达场景的宏伟，因为没有比例尺。这里有一个解决方法：包含一些人类视角的内容。

想一想。一条道路蜿蜒延伸至高耸山脉下的地平线，突然间，这些山峰成为引人注目的焦点。你看到那条路，你立刻就知道那些山是巨大的。

现在，想象一下在一棵令人敬畏的红杉旁边拍摄一个孤独的人物。瞬间，你不再只是在看一棵树；而是在看一棵树。你正在看着一座自然纪念碑。这个人成为了衡量这棵树是否宏伟的标尺。

当然，是否要加入人的因素完全取决于你！有些摄影师可能会认为这种方法混淆了自然场景的纯粹性，如果您有同样的感觉，那完全没问题。

此外，请记住平衡是关键。人的因素应该是补充，而不是分散。不要包含太多人性化的内容。相反，将人造元素融入构图中。如果做得好，效果绝对是惊人的。

8.充分利用颜色

风景摄影中的色彩思考不仅仅是捕捉美丽的日落。色彩管理可以决定照片的成败，影响观看者的情绪并引导他们的眼睛浏览构图。

那么，如何利用色彩来提升风景照片的品质呢？一种有效的方法是使用互补色。这些颜色在色轮上彼此相对。想想经典的蓝色和橙色组合。当您在晴朗的蓝天上拍摄阳光明媚的峡谷时，这些互补色可以形成鲜明的对比，为您的照片增添深度和兴奋感。

另一种方法涉及类似颜色，即色轮上相邻的颜色。这些可以使您的照片充满和谐感。想象一下在夕阳的金色光芒下斑驳的林地场景。黄色、橙色和红色的温暖色调可以营造出一种诱人、和平的氛围，吸引观众。

并且不要忽视颜色传达情绪的力量。颜色不仅仅是养眼的东西；它们可以作为一种情感语言。想象一下在山上捕捉一个有雾的早晨。蓝色和灰色的冷色调可能会唤起孤独或内省的感觉。

您还可以选择限制颜色以使特定元素脱颖而出。例如，蓝天映衬下的一片绿草在视觉上很有吸引力。但如果加上一朵鲜红色的郁金香，你就会突然成为一个引人注目的焦点。

最有经验的风景摄影师会对他们在镜头中包含或排除的颜色进行选择。意想不到的色彩可以吸引观众，但请记住，管理不善的色彩也会分散注意力。因此，下次构图时，请花点时间考虑一下色彩构成。您可能会对它产生的影响之大感到惊讶。

9.用长曝光技术捕捉运动

当大多数人想到风景时，他们会想到平静、安宁和被动的环境。然而，风景很少是完全静止的——如果你能传达这种运动，你就会为你的图像增添额外的戏剧性和情绪化。

（此外，您可以使用移动来创建引导线或产生引人注目的焦点。）

这就是你要做的：

首先，寻找运动，即使它很微妙。寻找树上的风、海滩上的波浪、溪流或瀑布上流过的水、飞翔的鸟儿或头顶上移动的云。将相机安装在三脚架上并构图。

其次，将快门速度延长至 1/30 秒或以上，然后设置曝光。请注意，不同的快门速度会给您带来截然不同的结果，因此最好在进行调整时拍摄多张照片。如果您在明亮的条件下工作，请考虑使用 ND 滤镜或偏光镜来减少照射到传感器的光线；这样，您可以进一步降低快门速度，而不必担心曝光过度。

请注意，风景摄影师只需尝试不同的快门速度即可实现各种不同的效果。例如，1/15 秒的镜头会模糊移动的水，但保留天空中的大量细节，如下所示：

而 30 秒的镜头会严重模糊水面并开始拉伸云层。

归根结底，与运动相关的工作非常有趣。只需拥抱这种效果，看看您能创造出什么！

10.黄金时段和蓝色时段拍照

黄金时段是日落之前和日出之后的时间，此时太阳低垂在天空中，产生美丽而温暖的光线。

黄金时段对于风景摄影来说是令人惊叹的。其一，阳光柔和地照亮了场景，强调了所有的小细节。看看金色的光芒如何完美地落在这些白雪覆盖的树木上：

黄金时段还提供了许多棉花糖色的天空，低太阳的角度在增强纹理的同时创造了有趣的阴影。

但黄金时段并不是一天中唯一适合风景摄影的时间。 蓝色时段（即日出之前和日落之后的时间）的光线也看起来令人惊叹：柔和、空灵、凉爽且神奇。 （另外，由于光线有限，蓝色时刻是进行长时间曝光风景拍摄的好时机！）

现在，您可能想知道：

我应该只在黄金时段和蓝色时段拍摄风景吗？或者其他时间也可以出去吗？

这是个好问题。根据我的经验，在阴天可以拍出美丽的风景照片，但你需要找到合适的拍摄对象，例如树叶、 森林和瀑布，我建议在你的构图中只包含很少的天空。

至于正午阳光下的风景摄影：尽可能避免。正午的阳光会投射出不讨人喜欢的阴影、褪色并产生大量令人不快的对比度。

11.拍摄亲密的风景照片

您看到的大多数风景照片都使用广角镜头。这是有充分理由的：广角镜头可以有效捕捉一览无余的远景。但有时候，真正的美在于细节。不要害怕近距离接触你的风景。这并不意味着您应该只使用微距镜头来突出森林地面上树叶的复杂性，尽管这是一种有效的方法。

长焦镜头也可以是您最好的朋友。这些镜头可让您将特定元素归零，例如有趣的岩层或一群生机勃勃的秋天树木。其结果可能是一幅感觉更亲密的图像，为观看者提供独特的视角。这里的风景充满了被忽视的宝藏，从山脉的图案到光线照射在树叶上的方式。打破广角拍摄的惯例，你可以在意想不到的地方发现美。

12. 测试风景照片创意

风景摄影非常受欢迎，正因为如此，有时会让人感觉每一张照片都被拍摄过，每一个角度都被探索过。但如果您愿意跳出传统的框框，创意的可能性是无限的。例如，有意的相机移动可以产生令人愉悦的模糊效果，既梦幻又艺术。这并不是风景摄影中经常被推崇的晶莹剔透、超细节的照片，但抽象的结果本身就可以令人惊叹。

想要更多？考虑自由镜头。该技术涉及拆下镜头并将其固定在相机机身前面，稍微倾斜以创建独特的焦平面。这可能会增加意想不到的模糊和漏光，为熟悉的景观带来新鲜感。

也不要让自己局限于传统镜头。鱼眼镜头等特种镜头可以为您的拍摄带来全新的视角，以一种视觉上有趣的方式扭曲现实。关键是要放弃先入为主的观念。让您的创造力引领潮流。

13.不要害怕恶劣的天气

景观场景可能会因天气而发生巨大变化，因此您必须提前计划并仔细选择时间和地点。

正如我上面强调的，日出和日落时的部分云层覆盖会形成令人惊叹的天空（在蓝色时段部分云层覆盖看起来也很棒！）。但其他类型的天气也非常适合风景摄影，包括：

  • 多雾路段
  • 雨
  • 乌云密布，乌云密布
  • 雪
  • 彩虹

不幸的是，许多天气事件不会持续很长时间，因此时刻关注天气预报非常重要。如果您预计会出现雾、雪或暴风雨，请提前选择您的位置。雾和雪在森林场景中看起来很棒，而雨和暴风云可以极大地增强海滩和海洋的拍摄效果。

专业提示：恶劣的天气虽然非常上镜，但也可能很危险！务必告诉朋友或家人您计划去哪里，始终穿戴适当的防护装备，并为您的设备携带适当的防护装备。我建议使用防水相机盖，不过您可以随时使用改装的垃圾袋和一些橡皮筋（将其固定在镜头周围）。

14.拍摄夜间风景

夜间摄影就像步入一个全新的领域，虽然我无法在这里完全介绍它，但我可以为您提供足够的入门知识。

你看，夜景提供了天体奇观，但它们需要一些特殊的技能和装备。首先，也是最重要的，了解您的位置。当您只能使用手电筒照亮潜在的构图时，侦察就变得更加重要。

坚固的三脚架是夜间摄影的最佳朋友。长时间曝光对于捕捉弱光至关重要，任何相机抖动都会破坏拍摄效果。您可能会使用 20 秒或更长的快门速度，因此请确保您的三脚架能够胜任这项工作。

对天文摄影感兴趣？具有大光圈（例如 f/2.8）的广角镜头可以成为您套件中的宝贵补充。这种设置可以让您捕捉夜空，同时将星星的移动保持在最低限度。为此，您可能需要将 ISO 设置提高到 1600 左右或更高。但别担心，夜空的噪音是很宽容的。

15. 在降雪之后（或期间）拍摄

很少有场景能像白雪覆盖的风景那样迷人。世界仿佛静止了，裹上了柔软的白色毯子。然而，捕捉这些冬季仙境也面临着一系列挑战。首先，您的相机需要额外保养。如果拍摄时雪仍在下，请考虑为您的装备使用防雨罩。手边准备一块布来擦掉镜头上的积雪也能起到救星的作用。

保护好设备后，就该发挥创意了。白雪覆盖的背景可以带来戏剧性的对比。想象一下白色天空下一棵光秃秃的树的黑色轮廓。这里的关键是拥抱简单性。白雪覆盖的场景已经给人一种简约的感觉。不要弄乱它；让雪自己说话。

注意：快速的温度变化可能会导致镜头上形成凝结。为了避免在拍摄结束返回室内时出现此问题，请在进入温暖环境之前将相机密封在袋子或密封隔间中。将装备带入室内后，请等待几个小时再打开包；这样，您的相机就有时间适应室内温度。

16.不要忽视浅景深技术

深景深几乎是风景摄影的代名词。您通常希望从前景到地平线的所有事物都清晰对焦。但这里有一个转折点：使用浅景深可以给你的图像带来完全不同的、神奇的品质。将光圈打开到 f/2.8 或 f/4 可以让大量光线进入，并显着模糊背景。

关键是要专注于你的主题。假设您想要突出显示一块岩石或一片草地。调整你的注意力就可以了。然后，当您拍照时，背景会变成奶油色、梦幻般的模糊效果。

这不是典型的风景照片，这就是重点。您可以创建更亲密、更精美的外观，突出大景观中的小细节。

17. 进行黑白风景摄影

Color certainly has its charm. The pop of orange in a sunset or the vibrancy of a field of wildflowers can be stunning. Yet, there's something captivating about black-and-white landscape photography. With a focus on contrast, texture, and form, black-and-white photos strip away distractions. They direct your attention to the core of the scene.

In the old days, photographers started with black-and-white because that's all they had. So when you're shooting in monochrome, you're kind of paying homage to the roots of landscape photography. Plus, you don't have to decide right away whether you'll keep the photo in black-and-white. If you're shooting in RAW, which I highly recommend, you can make that choice later during post-processing.

That said, it's useful to consider black-and-white conversion while shooting. Look for elements that will pop in grayscale, such as stark contrasts or intricate textures, and really commit to a monochrome approach!

18. Think about the horizon line

This landscape photography tip is quick and easy:

Always pay attention to the horizon line, and do whatever you can to keep it straight .

A crooked horizon line looks incredibly amateurish, and while you can fix this in post-processing, you'll lose pixels along the edge of the frame – which will reduce your ability to print large and (even worse!) can cut off key compositional elements.

So make sure you get it right in-camera! Here, viewfinder gridlines can be helpful. Most cameras have these activated by default, but if you don't see them, head into the settings menu and switch them on.

And if you use the gridlines but you still struggle to keep things straight, you might consider purchasing a bubble level. You can attach one of these to your camera's hot shoe, and you can use it as a reference when setting up new compositions.

19. Combine light and shadow

You might have heard the saying that photography is the art of painting with light. Well, it's not just about the light; it's also about the shadows. Combining light and shadow in your landscape shots can result in some truly stunning images. The contrast between illuminated areas and dark shadows adds depth, creates mood, and draws the eye to key parts of the frame.

Waiting for the perfect interplay of light and shadow often requires patience. One of the best times to capture this is when the sky is overcast, and the sun is peeking through the clouds. When that ray of sunshine breaks through and lights up a portion of the landscape while leaving the rest in shadow, you've got yourself a golden opportunity.

Another scenario is during sunrise or sunset. Low-angle light naturally creates long shadows and can illuminate just the tops of hills and trees while leaving other areas dark. The contrasting elements give your photo a dynamic, three-dimensional feel that flat lighting just can't achieve.

So, the next time you're out with your camera and the lighting seems challenging, don't pack up. Stick around. Watch the light and shadow dance across the landscape. You might just find that the most captivating shots come when you blend both elements harmoniously.

20. Try HDR techniques

HDR photography sometimes gets a bad rap, largely because of overdone, unrealistic results. But this doesn't mean you should shy away from it. When you're faced with a challenging scene, such as a sunset over the ocean, your camera might not capture the full range of light. That's where HDR comes in handy. The idea is to take multiple shots at different exposure levels. One for the shadows, one for the midtones, and one for the highlights.

Once you've got your series of photos, the next step is blending them together. Software like Adobe Photoshop or Lightroom can merge these images into one. The result? A photo with details in both the darkest and brightest areas, much like how our eyes perceive the world.

But remember, subtlety is your friend. It's easy to go overboard with contrast and saturation sliders. Less is often more when it comes to HDR in landscape photography. Aim for a balanced, natural look to bring out the best in your photos.

21. Change your point of view

Are you looking to capture strikingly unique landscape images?

Then you've got to move past those basic “lookout” shots, where you point your camera at a beautiful scene, then snap a photo.

Instead, take a little more time with each landscape scene. In particular, look for an interesting angle or point of view, where you approach the composition from an interesting direction. You should have fun with this; try getting down low, finding a high vantage point, walking off to the left or the right, or even shooting from directly above (see the next tip!).

Often, these unconventional images are astonishingly powerful, in part because they show the landscape from a never-before-seen perspective.

It's important to bear in mind, however, that you should still pay careful attention to your gear and lighting. A unique perspective can add a lot to an image, but the best landscape shots combine well-chosen gear, great lighting, and a great perspective for a beautiful result.

22. Capture aerial landscape images

Taking your photography to the sky opens up a new world of possibilities. Aerial landscape photography has grown in popularity, thanks largely to the accessibility of drones. These nifty flying cameras allow you to capture views that were once only possible from helicopters or planes.

But capturing great aerial shots isn't as easy as simply sending a drone up and hitting the shutter button. It's an art form that has its own rules and challenges. Your composition skills are more important than ever. After all, from up high, you can see patterns and shapes that are invisible from ground level. Rivers look like veins, roads like stitches, and forests like broccoli!

When you're starting out with aerial photography, I recommend studying the work of other drone photographers. Look for elements that make their shots effective. Is it the angle? The lighting? The way they've framed a particular landscape feature? As you dissect these factors, you'll find it easier to replicate them in your own work.

Of course, safety and legality are paramount. Always abide by the rules governing drone use in your area. Most countries have regulations about where you can and can't fly, and some require a license. Make sure you're informed before taking off.

Once you're up there, the sky's the limit—literally. Whether you're capturing the intricate patterns of a cityscape or the sweeping vistas of a mountain range, aerial photography brings a fresh perspective to landscapes. With some practice and a good eye for composition, you'll be creating jaw-dropping images in no time.

23. Don't forget to edit your landscape photos

If you shoot digital—and most of us do these days—editing isn't optional; it's essential. Don't think of editing as cheating or as something that sullies the “purity” of your photos. Trust me, even the best photos can benefit from a little post-processing.

Imagine editing as the final brushstroke in your creative process. Sure, you can get great shots straight out of the camera, but they'll almost always look better with a bit of tweaking. Simple things like adjusting exposure, white balance, and contrast can make a world of difference. These basic tweaks aim to make the photo match what your eyes saw. That's what we call “getting it right in camera.”

But the fun doesn't stop there. Editing software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop offers tons of creative possibilities. Want to emphasize the golden hue of a sunset? You can do that. Fancy adding a vignette to make your subject pop? It's all possible. And as you grow more confident, you can start playing with advanced techniques like dodging and burning. This helps to add a sense of depth and dimension to your landscapes.

In essence, editing allows you to achieve the photo you envisioned – or even to put your personal stamp on a photo. So don't skip this step. Even a few small adjustments can transform a good photo into a masterpiece.

Landscape photography tips: conclusion

Now that you've finished this article, you're ready to capture some stunning landscape photography! From choosing the right lens and filters to experimenting with settings and creative methods, these guidelines are designed to arm you with the knowledge you need to create captivating images.

But remember: Landscape photography is a journey. It's not just about capturing pretty scenes; it's about conveying your own perspective of the world. Whether you're an absolute beginner or someone looking to refine your skills, always remember that the best tool you have is your own vision.

So grab your camera, head out, and find a subject to shoot. See what you can create, and let your inner artist run wild!

If you're struggling to choose the right travel photography gear, you've come to the right place.

You see, new travel photographers are always asking me about the equipment they should buy. And over time, I've developed a standard set of items that every travel shooter must own, from the absolute beginner to the serious professional.

Below, I share my list of essentials; it features all of the basics, including camera, lens, and accessory recommendations.

(By the way, a quick piece of advice before we start: Get adequate insurance to cover your camera and accessories. Accidents and thefts can – and will – happen. Be prepared!)

So if you're ready to put together a top-notch travel photography kit, then let's dive right in, starting with the most important gear item of all:

1. A camera

Needless to say, every travel photographer needs at least one camera (and if you're serious about travel photography, I'd really recommend you carry two: a main body and a backup).

What travel photography camera is best? Honestly, there are so many different choices, plenty of which are capable of great images, so the only way to really know what's right is for you to think about your shooting preferences, then do some serious research.

But I do have a few pieces of advice.

For one, make sure that your camera is portable enough to carry all around the world, yet offers strong enough image quality to create stunning prints. It might sound like a tall order, but you can find entry-level mirrorless cameras, DSLRs, and even point-and-shoot models that are small, lightweight, and take great pictures (they won't break the bank, either).

Of course, there are also pro-level cameras that fit the bill, but they're far pricier. Professional travel photographers tend to use high-end mirrorless and DSLR cameras, which range from around $1,500 to $5,000 USD. One advantage of these cameras, in addition to the insane low-light capabilities and high megapixel counts, is the (often) robust weather sealing. If you plan to shoot in rain, snow, blowing sand, or sea spray, weather sealing is hugely beneficial. It might even be a must-have feature.

If you're not sure whether a specific camera is right for you, I highly recommend renting before you buy. There are plenty of great online rental companies (and you can find in-person rental companies locally, too). Grab the camera for a day or three, go out and take some photos, and see what you think. You may end up frustrated or you may fall in love – but after a few hours, you'll know whether it's a camera worth buying.

By the way, when you're ready to purchase, shop around. Don't forget that you can always buy secondhand cameras; these cost half as much but are often in outstanding condition.

2. Lenses

Usually, cameras come with just one low-quality lens, or they might come “body only,” which means that you'll need to purchase a lens separately.

Lenses do make a major difference, so I recommend you think about your travel photography lens choice very carefully. Wide-angle lenses, for instance, will get you completely different results from telephoto lenses. And wide-aperture lenses will let you shoot in very low light, though you'll pay for it in money, size, and weight.

To start, you'll need a workhorse lens, which you can use for most of your travel photography. It should offer a good range of focal lengths, should be relatively lightweight, and should offer decent optical quality. I'd recommend looking into 24-70mm lenses, which are great for everything from landscapes to travel portraits . (In fact, you could get away with only purchasing a 24-70mm lens; they really are that versatile!)

If your budget allows it, however, I do recommend you add a telephoto lens to complement your workhorse lens. A 70-200mm lens, for instance, is great for tighter landscapes, architectural details, and even large (or tame) wildlife.

Over time, you can always build up your lens collection further by adding macro or prime lenses, but if you can start with a 24-70mm lens and a 70-200mm lens, or even just a 24-70mm lens, you'll be in great shape.

Here's my basic list of lenses, which I carry on every trip:

  • A 24-70mm f/2.8 zoom
  • A 70-200mm f/2.8 zoom
  • A 50mm f/1.2 prime
  • A 100mm f/2.8 macro

3. A tripod

Beginner travel photographers might not like the idea of purchasing a tripod – after all, it can be expensive, it can be a hassle to transport, and it'll slow down your shooting – but here's the thing:

A tripod is one of the most invaluable travel photography gear items you will ever own. In fact, ask any travel photographer to name their favorite accessory, and they'll most likely say a tripod.

What makes tripods so special?

For one, without a tripod, you cannot take photos that require slow shutter speeds . Image stabilization technology is great, but you can't use IS to capture ultra-long exposures at night; try it, and you'll likely end up with a series of blurry photos.

And yes, tripods do slow you down, but that's often a good thing. Tripods mean that you spend a bit more time thinking and composing rather than just snapping away.

There are plenty of amazing tripods, and the one that you choose will come down to personal preference, budget, and weight tolerance. Most travel photographers go with carbon fiber tripods, as they are stable and lightweight, and I recommend that you do the same.

Now, when you're looking at tripods, you'll probably notice plenty of cheap options – in the $50 to $150 range – and you'll wonder: Why can't I get one of those?

Well, you can , but they'll often weigh a ton. You might not think that 7 lb sounds like a lot, but try carrying a 7 lb tripod for an entire day (along with your camera, lenses, and accessories) and you'll wish you had paid more money for a lighter model.

And if you find a cheap tripod that doesn't weigh a ton, it's likely very unstable. Do you really want to rely on something cheap and flimsy to hold up your expensive camera? In my view, you should always choose the best tripod that you can afford. It'll last you a long time, anyway, and will be well worth the initial investment.

4. A camera bag

Tripods might be the most important travel photography accessory you'll ever own, but camera bags come in as a close second, so make sure you buy a good, durable, comfortable product.

You see, camera bags often go unnoticed, yet not only do they keep your equipment safe while in transit, but they also hold your equipment when you are photographing at your destination. They protect your precious cameras and lenses from sand, rain, and snow, and they ensure you remain comfortable when walking or hiking from location to location.

There are lots of camera bags to choose from, and they vary in terms of size, durability, comfort, accessories, and cost. You'll need to pick a bag that works for you, and as you become more experienced, you may want to buy different bags for different scenarios.

For instance, if I'm hiking or out in the wilderness, I carry a large, comfortable bag, one that's good for long walks and that contains plenty of room for equipment, water, and more. On the other hand, if I'm shooting in a city, I'll go with a smaller bag or even a shoulder bag, which holds less gear but won't get in the way.

5. Memory cards

So you're standing in front of a breathtaking sunset, colors swirling in the sky like an artist's palette. Your camera's at the ready. But wait—your camera displays a warning that you're almost out of memory. The beauty of the moment fades as you frantically sift through your photos, deciding which ones to delete to make room. Frustrating, isn't it? To avoid this scenario, stock up on memory cards. Lots of them.

How many should you bring? Well, that depends. It's a balancing act between the length of your trip, your shooting style, the megapixels your camera has, and the capacity of the cards you're considering. If you're someone who loves shooting for long stretches, or if you're a fan of burst mode, then you'll need hefty storage—say, around 500 GB or even more for extended trips.

Don't just think about quantity; consider the safety of your digital treasures. I'll talk about external hard drives later, but even before that, invest in a quality memory card case. These nifty little containers shield your cards from elements like rain, dirt, and dust. It's a small investment that can save you a lot of heartache.

6. Extra batteries

Switching gears, let's talk about the lifeblood of your camera: batteries. And just as you wouldn't leave for a trip with just one memory card, you shouldn't go without spare batteries either.

The need for extra batteries becomes even more pressing when you can't predict your access to a power outlet. Maybe you're in a remote village or trekking through the wilderness; it's not like you can just plug your charger into a tree.

While original batteries can be pricey, third-party options usually offer a more budget-friendly alternative without sacrificing much in terms of performance. In warm climates and where you know you'll have frequent access to power, one spare should suffice. But if you're headed to a colder climate, or places where charging might be a challenge, 3-5 spare batteries would be more appropriate, especially if you're using modern mirrorless cameras, which tend to be power-hungry.

7. An external hard drive

Traveling the world with your camera is incredible. Yet, that moment of joy can turn to panic if something happens to your memory cards. This is where an external hard drive steps in as your safety net. I strongly recommend that every traveler keep one in their kit. When you get back to your lodging each night, you can transfer the day's photos onto the hard drive. This provides a dual safety net—keeping your shots safe and freeing up memory space for the next day.

Hard drives are quite affordable now, and even drives with terabytes of storage won't break the bank. The ones built for durability are particularly good for travel. They can handle a few bumps on the road and most are shock-resistant. You don't want a little tumble to wipe out your irreplaceable photos.

8. A remote release

A tripod serves as the bedrock for many great shots. But let's extend that setup a bit. A remote release might not be the first thing you pack, but oh, the difference it makes. We're talking about crisp, clear shots when the sun's gone down or when you're indoors. Sure, you could use your camera's built-in timer or even your smartphone to snap a photo. But a remote release eliminates any risk of camera shake, which can ruin an otherwise perfect shot.

Especially useful for low-light photography, this tiny device allows you to trigger the camera without touching it. This is crucial when you're working with slow shutter speeds to get that perfect exposure. What's more, these gadgets aren't a major investment. Basic models often cost less than $20. So if you're planning to capture the serene twilight or the dynamic city lights, do consider adding a remote release to your kit.

9. A raincover

Mother Nature is unpredictable! You're in a beautiful location, the light is perfect, and then—bam! Raindrops start falling. If you don't want your camera to be a casualty of unexpected weather, a rain cover is a smart addition to your gear. Think of it as an insurance policy for your camera, safeguarding your investment from water damage.

A basic rain cover should do the trick for most situations. These are generally affordable and easy to slip over your camera and lens. They're made of water-resistant materials like nylon or polyethylene and usually have a clear panel so you can still see your camera's settings. But if you find yourself in a situation where you have to improvise, a trash bag secured with rubber bands can also be a makeshift solution.

This gear isn't glamorous, but it's effective. And when you're far from home, capturing scenes you've only dreamt of, practicality trumps glamour every time.

10. A cleaning kit

Switching gears, let's discuss hygiene—not for you, but for your camera. Whether you're trekking through the Amazon or wandering through the streets of Paris, your camera is at risk. Elements like rain, dust, and even snow can turn from scenic details into gear-ruining nightmares. So, just as you wouldn't venture out without your personal toiletries, don't forget your camera's cleaning kit.

A basic kit doesn't have to be bulky. A small pouch can hold all the essentials: microfiber cloths for your lens, a rocket blower to force out the pesky dust, and a small brush to reach into the crevices of your camera body. These simple tools can be lifesavers, ensuring that your camera remains functional and your photos remain clear.

11. Filters

Your camera captures light, but you control the quality of that light. Filters can be game-changers, particularly for travel photographers capturing diverse scenes. Say you're photographing a lake surrounded by lush trees. A polarizing filter will minimize glare on the water and make those green leaves pop. The difference it makes is like night and day.

Neutral density filters are another key accessory. These are useful when you want to experiment with long-exposure shots. Maybe you're near a flowing river and you want to capture that silky-smooth water effect. A neutral density filter will let you shoot at slower shutter speeds without overexposing your image.

Last but not least, let's talk about protective filters like UV or clear filters. These may not dramatically alter your images, but they safeguard your valuable lens from scratches, smudges, and even minor falls. I say it's a lot easier—and cheaper—to replace a filter than a lens.

Essential travel photography gear: final words

Buying your first camera, lenses, and accessories can be a daunting prospect.

But if you pay careful attention to this list, do your research, and get the absolute essentials, then your kit will turn out great. You can always add more specialized gear over time!

What is shutter speed in photography, and how can you use it to create stunning photos?

Shutter speed is a foundational photographic concept – one that every beginner photographer must master. Once you know how to use shutter speed, you'll be able to capture sharp photos at will. You'll also be prepared to capture interesting artistic effects (such as slow shutter speed blur ).

In this article, I'm going to take you through all the shutter speed basics, including:

  • A simple definition of shutter speed
  • The effects that shutter speed has on your images
  • The different (and importance) of slow versus fast shutter speeds
  • How to use different shutter speeds for outstanding results

So if you're ready to become a shutter speed photography expert, then let's dive right in!

What is shutter speed?

Shutter speed is the length of time the camera shutter is open while the camera takes a photo.

You press the shutter button, the shutter opens for a predetermined time period (ie, the shutter speed), then the shutter closes and the image is complete.

When the shutter is open, light hits the camera sensor; therefore, the longer the shutter speed, the more light the sensor receives. This has various effects, as discussed in the next section.

Note that shutter speed is measured in seconds (or fractions of a second). Here are a few common shutter speeds:

  • 10s
  • 1s
  • 1/10s
  • 1/30s
  • 1/60s
  • 1/125s
  • 1/250s
  • 1/500s
  • 1/1000s
  • 1/1600s
  • 1/2000s

The list begins with a long, 10-second shutter speed, but the shutter speeds get shorter and shorter, ending with a lightning-fast 1/2000s shutter speed.

Note that the shutter speed measurements listed above certainly aren't comprehensive. Most DSLRs and mirrorless cameras let you select from 30-second shutter speeds all the way down to 1/4000s or 1/8000s, though you may also have access to a special mode – called Bulb mode – that lets you keep the shutter button open for your desired length of time.

Therefore, while most cameras offer several dozen basic shutter speed options (shutter speed presets , if you will), there are literally thousands of possible shutter speeds you can use, all of which expose the camera sensor to slightly different quantities of light. Make sense?

How shutter speed affects your photos

Shutter speed impacts your images in two key ways:

  1. It increases and decreases exposure (ie, image brightness)
  2. It increases and decreases sharpness (ie, image detail)

Let's take a look at each item in turn.

Shutter speed increases and decreases exposure

The longer the shutter speed, the more light that hits your camera sensor – and the brighter the image becomes .

So if you photograph a tree at 1/1000s, then you lower the shutter speed to 1s, your second image – with its slower shutter speed – will be noticeably brighter.

This has major consequences. Much of photography is about achieving the proper brightness, or exposure , for a scene, and by adjusting the shutter speed, you can get different results. For this reason, shutter speed is one of the three camera exposure variables (along with aperture and ISO ).

So when you're out with your camera, you'll need to adjust the shutter speed to achieve a nice, balanced exposure. The specifics will depend on the scene, but watch for blown-out highlights and clipped shadows. In other words, make sure you don't over or underexpose so heavily that you lose information in the lightest or darkest parts of the photo.

Shutter speed increases and decreases sharpness

Faster shutter speeds freeze motion. Slower shutter speeds blur motion.

So if you're photographing a bird in flight at 1/4000s, every feather will be crisp, even the flapping wings. But if you photograph that same bird at 1/15s, it will be an indecipherable blur.

Now, the shutter speed needed to freeze motion will change depending on the speed of the moving object. A feather drifting through the air may require a 1/200s shutter speed for maximum sharpness, while a fast-moving car may require 1/2000s or more.

A too-slow shutter speed is one of the main reasons why pictures come out blurry – so you should pay very close attention to your shutter speed value. Always make sure it's fast enough to get the results you're after.

How to set the shutter speed on your camera

The precise shutter speed mechanisms vary from camera to camera – but changing the shutter speed is usually as simple as rotating a dial (to learn all the specifics, I recommend you check your camera manual).

Note that your ability to adjust the shutter speed will change depending on your camera mode.

If you use Auto mode, your camera will select the shutter speed for you, and you will have zero ability to make changes.

If you use Manual mode , you can dial in the shutter speed at will (and you can also independently select your aperture and ISO).

If you use Shutter Priority mode , you can select the shutter speed and the ISO, while your camera will select the aperture for the optimal exposure (based on its evaluation of the scene).

If you use Aperture Priority mode, you can select the aperture and ISO, while your camera will select the shutter speed for an optimal exposure (again, based on its evaluation of the scene).

Different camera modes are good for different situations, so don't just pick a mode and stick to it; instead, learn to adjust your mode dial depending on your photographic needs.

How to choose the perfect shutter speed: step by step

Struggling to pick the perfect shutter speed? You're not alone.

But while selecting the best shutter speed for your shooting situation might seem hard, it's actually easy – once you get the hang of it. Here's the two-step process I recommend:

Step 1: Determine the lowest-possible shutter speed that will get you a sharp shot

Look at your scene. Ask yourself: Are any subjects moving ? And if so, what shutter speed do I need to freeze them?

You'll get better at determining the lowest-possible shutter speed over time, but at first, it will take a lot of trial and error. Here's a list of minimum sharp shutter speeds to get you started:

  • Water flowing: 1/125s
  • People walking: 1/250s
  • People/animals running: 1/500s
  • Cars driving: 1/1000s
  • Birds flying: 1/2000s

Also note that, if your scene has zero movement, you cannot simply select whatever shutter speed you like. If you're handholding your camera, then your hands will shake, and this will create blur – unless your shutter speed is fast enough.

The lowest-possible handheld shutter speed varies from person to person, plus it depends on your lens (longer lenses increase camera shake). And thanks to image stabilization technology, some cameras and lenses allow for slower handheld shooting. But I'd recommend keeping the shutter speed above 1/60s or so for short lenses, and 1/160s or so for long lenses, at least until you've done some tests.

Of course, if you're shooting a scene with no movement, you do have another option: you can shoot with a tripod. Assuming your tripod is sturdy, it will let you drop your shutter speed as low as you like (which is how you can create beautiful moving water effects, as I discuss later in this article!).

Step 2: Boost your shutter speed (or adjust other variables) for the proper exposure

At this point, you should know your minimum shutter speed for a sharp shot. You shouldn't drop below this speed – but you can always go above it, depending on your exposure needs.

If you're in Manual mode, check your camera's exposure bar (in the viewfinder). If the scene is overexposed, go ahead and boost the shutter speed.

If you're in Shutter Priority mode, your camera will automatically select an aperture for a good exposure. But feel free to raise the shutter speed as long as your camera continues to choose an aperture you like.

On the other hand, if the scene is underexposed according to your camera's exposure bar, you'll need to change other camera settings to get the right exposure. Consider widening the aperture – but if this isn't possible, you'll need to raise the ISO.

Do not drop the shutter speed, however. Better to increase the ISO for a noisy image than to end up with unwanted blur.

就是这样！ To recap: Start by identifying your lowest-possible shutter speed for a sharp shot, then simply make tweaks for the optimal exposure.

That way, you get a crisp photo – with a balanced exposure, too.

Slow shutter speed photography

The advice I've given above is perfect for situations where you want to freeze a moving subject.

But what if a sharp shot isn't your goal? What if, instead, you want to creatively blur your photo for a beautiful effect?

You see, blur isn't always bad; it can communicate motion, plus it can look truly breathtaking, as in this waterfall shot:

In deliberate motion-blur situations, you should set your camera to Manual mode, then dial in the exact shutter speed you're after.

At this point, you should check your camera's exposure bar and adjust the aperture and/or ISO for a good exposure.

Note that you definitely need a tripod for this type of long-exposure photography. Otherwise, the entire shot will blur!

Pro tip: If you're struggling to get a slow enough shutter speed without overexposing the image, consider using a neutral density filter , which blocks out light and is perfect for long exposure shooting . It's commonly used to create long-exposure images in bright conditions.

Alternatively, you can shoot in near darkness (either indoors or at night). That's how this subway image was captured:

What shutter speed is best? Basic recommendations

Now that you're familiar with the ins and outs of selecting a shutter speed, I'd like to share a few basic recommendations for selecting the right shutter speed. These recommendations won't always work, but they should certainly offer you a good starting point when adjusting your camera settings.

The best shutter speeds for landscape photography

Landscape photographers generally have two shutter-related goals:

  1. Get the image sharp from foreground to background
  2. Create artistic motion blur in moving water and clouds

Now, foreground-to-background sharpness refers to a deep depth of field . And while this isn't directly related to shutter speed, the longer the shutter speed, the easier it becomes to achieve a deep depth of field.

(Why? The depth of field is controlled by the aperture – and lengthier shutter speeds allow you to adjust the aperture without underexposing the scene.)

Plus, as I explained in a previous section, if you want artistic motion blur, you need to lengthen the shutter speed.

Bottom line: Landscape photography thrives on long exposures. Most landscape photographers shoot at 1s to 1/200s in bright daylight, and as the light falls, the shutter speeds slow. Many landscape shooters work at 1/30s to 30s (or more) around sunrise, sunset, and at night.

Such lengthy shutter speeds are only possible with a tripod. If you don't have a tripod, then it's often best to drop your shutter speed as low as you can go without creating camera shake (often around 1/60s or so).

The best shutter speeds for portrait photography

Portrait photographers can be pretty flexible when choosing shutter speeds. The key goal is to keep your shots sharp – by avoiding camera shake as well as motion blur – but because you can generally instruct your subject and work from a stable position, this shouldn't be too tough.

If you're shooting a stationary subject, feel free to drop your shutter speed to around 1/80s or so (though 1/200s is safer).

And if you're shooting a moving subject, such as a person dancing, I'd recommend working at 1/500s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for wildlife and bird photography

Bird and wildlife photography generally involves capturing fast-moving subjects with long lenses.

Therefore, you should generally use the fastest shutter speed you can get away with. For slower-moving animals, 1/500s is a reasonable starting point (and you can go lower if the animal is completely stationary – just make sure you keep your lens on a tripod or handheld as stably as possible).

For fast-moving animals and birds, 1/1000s is the place to start. And when action is occurring, I'd really recommend pushing your shutter speed to 1/2000s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for street photography

Street photographers tend to be less concerned with sharpness than other shooters, so your choice of shutter speed isn't nearly as important.

That said, if you're walking while shooting and/or photographing walking people, 1/250s is a safe starting point. If both you and your subject are stationary, then you can often shoot at 1/100s or slower (assuming you're using good handholding techniques and relatively short lenses).

Shutter speed in photography: final words

Now that you've finished this article, you're well-equipped to create some gorgeous photos.

So head out with your camera and test out different shutter speeds. Get familiar with your options. And try the two-step process I outlined above!

What is the shutter speed in a camera?

The shutter speed refers to the length of time the shutter is open when you press the shutter button. The longer the shutter is open, the more light that hits the sensor, and the brighter the image becomes.

Shutter speeds around 1/1000s and above are fast, while shutter speeds in the 1/100s to 1/1000s range are average, and shutter speeds from 1/100s on down are slow.

A higher shutter speed helps guarantee a sharp photo. However, if your subject isn't moving, a high shutter speed can be overkill (and it will decrease the image exposure, which can be a problem). Also, a slower shutter speed can create artistic effects (such as blurry water).

A basic safe shutter speed is 1/250s, which will let you capture sharp shots of stationary and slow-moving subjects. But if you're photographing cars driving, birds in flight, or other fast action, you'll generally need to shoot at 1/1000s or above.

摄影中的手动对焦：终极指南首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是蒂姆·吉尔布雷斯。

如果你想拍摄始终清晰的照片，那么你必须学会​​手动对焦。是的，手动对焦（在某种程度上）是先进的，但它可以成为一种改变游戏规则的技术——如果你知道何时以及如何使用它。

下面，我将分享您开始使用手动对焦时需要了解的所有信息。我提供了有关如何获得出色结果的分步说明，此外我还解释了您何时确实要考虑使用手动对焦（以及何时应避免手动对焦，因为它并不总是一件好事！）。

让我们从基础知识开始深入探讨：

什么是手动对焦？

每张图像都需要对焦，镜头会移动其元素，直到在特定位置获得清晰度。默认情况下，大多数镜头会自动执行此操作，这称为自动对焦。但是，作为摄影师，您可以覆盖镜头的自动对焦机制，并通过镜筒上的环调整对焦。

这就是手动对焦：您可以控制、旋转镜头的对焦环并改变焦点。

通过手动对焦，您无需让相机和镜头决定对焦位置，而是由您自己完成所有操作。但为什么手动对焦很有用呢？它适合你吗？

为什么手动对焦很重要？

现代自动对焦技术很棒，但在某些情况下它会遇到困难。它可能会将焦点锁定在场景的错误部分，并且可能无法完全锁定焦点。

以下是自动对焦技术经常出错的几个场景：

  • 在黑暗中对焦时
  • 近距离对焦时
  • 在两个主导科目之间进行选择时
  • 通过前景元素对焦时

现在，相机和镜头的自动对焦技术的功效可能会有所不同。某些相机提供自动对焦算法，能够以出色的精度检测眼睛和面部，并且某些镜头即使在高倍率场景下也快如闪电。

但总的来说，大多数相机和镜头有时都会出错，这就是手动对焦如此重要的原因。如果您知道如何手动对焦，则可以在需要时关闭自动对焦，并且仍然可以拍摄照片。因此，这是一项宝贵的技能，我建议几乎每个摄影师都学习这项技能，无论他们认为手动对焦有多么无用。

如何手动对焦：一步一步

首先，找到相机或镜头上的对焦模式开关。它可能会标有“AF/MF”，其中“AF”激活自动对焦，“MF”激活手动对焦。 Like this:

然后将您的设置切换到“MF”。

（请注意，某些镜头无法手动对焦；在这种情况下，您将找不到任何开关。如果您不确定是否属于这种情况，请检查镜头手册。）

其次，找到对焦环，它通常位于镜筒中部附近（如果您使用定焦镜头）或靠近镜筒末端（如果您使用变焦镜头）。

通过相机取景器查看，然后将对焦环旋转到一侧。

当场景的不同区域进入和失焦时，您应该立即看到焦点发生变化。

现在，当您遇到需要手动对焦的情况时（下一节将详细介绍！），您只需转动对焦环，直到主要拍摄对象清晰对焦。

听起来很容易，对吧？可能是这样，尽管有时很难通过相机取景器感知焦点，所以我有一些提示给您：

  1. 切换到相机的实时取景功能，您可以在 LCD 上预览相机传感器的实时图像。放大图像，然后调整焦距直到您看到——同时放大！ – 完美的清晰度。
  2. 考虑缩小光圈，让自己有更大的误差范围。如果您以 f/2.8 拍摄，则必须正确对焦。然而，如果您以 f/8 拍摄，则可以不用担心稍微偏离拍摄对象。
  3. 拍摄手动对焦图像后，检查 LCD 上的结果。与上面提到的实时预览一样，放大以便您可以绝对确定您获得了所需的清晰度。

什么时候应该使用手动对焦？

自动对焦技术很棒，我当然不建议一直切换到手动对焦。相反，您需要在某些情况下使用它，例如：

微距和特写摄影

当您以高倍率拍摄时，镜头往往会寻找焦点 - 当它们最终锁定拍摄对象时，它通常位于错误的位置。

这就是为什么手动对焦非常有用。您可以使用它来更快地获得焦点并将焦点精确地设置在您想要的位置。

事实上，我建议摄影师在对静止物体进行微距摄影时始终使用手动对焦。它使这个过程变得更加容易。 （手动对焦移动的宏观物体（例如昆虫）比较困难 - 这实际上取决于您的设备和您喜欢的工作方法，因此请随意尝试手动对焦和自动对焦，看看哪种效果最好。）

弱光情况

自动对焦在弱光场景下会很困难，尤其是在没有任何形式的照明的情况下拍摄时（例如，在夜间的沙漠中、在黑暗的小巷中等）。

你的镜头会搜寻并且永远不会锁定任何东西，因此手动对焦是必须的。

不幸的是，黑暗也使手动对焦变得困难，所以我建议您使用上面讨论的实时取景技术。通过 LCD 预览镜头、放大并确保在继续之前已确定焦点。

请注意，不同相机的低光对焦能力有所不同。首先尝试自动对焦，但如果不起作用，请在晚上剩下的时间里切换到手动对焦。

浅景深场景

使用超宽光圈可以很艺术，但这种创造性技术也带来了挑战：由于清晰度窗口超窄，对焦必须精确。

换句话说，如果您不仔细对焦，就很容易错过目标并意外地稍微聚焦在拍摄对象的前面或后面。

现在，有时在使用大光圈时自动对焦可以发挥出色的作用。如果您正在拍摄肖像并且您的相机提供了眼部自动对焦选项，则您可能不需要切换到手动对焦，并且可以使用相机的自动对焦模式拍摄一致清晰的照片。

但并非所有相机都提供眼部自动对焦，并且很多时候眼部自动对焦对您的拍摄对象不起作用 - 这就是为什么在使用浅景深时，我强烈建议您考虑手动对焦。

这样，您就可以仔细地将焦点设置在您想要的位置，并确保您绝对成功拍摄。

街头摄影

街头摄影的步伐可能会令人兴奋。快速的动作、意想不到的时刻——它们几乎在乞求被捕捉。考虑到场景的速度，您可能认为自动对焦是最好的方法。当然，自动对焦非常适合街头摄影，许多经验丰富的摄影师都依赖它！

但不要太快地放弃街头摄影的手动对焦。世界上一些最好的街头拍摄者使用一种称为区域对焦的技术，您可以拨入相对较窄的光圈 - 这为您提供了良好的景深窗口 - 然后提前手动对焦。

这种方法的优点在于，随着时间的推移，您将准确地了解焦点窗口所在的位置。然后，当您发现完美的主题或场景时，您根本不必为对焦而苦恼。您只需就位并拍摄即可。

因此，手动对焦并不会减慢您的速度，实际上可以消除延迟，并可以拍摄出一些非凡的照片。请记住，在街头摄影中相信手动对焦并不是一个限制；这是一个以新的、有益的方式掌握你的手艺的机会。

创意效果

拍摄一张在人群中脱颖而出的照片确实是一件美妙的事情。创造令人惊叹的原创图像的最佳方法之一是尝试创造性的效果，例如有意的相机移动、故意的失焦和直通技术。但为了获得最佳效果，您总是需要手动对焦。

为什么？想象一下，您想要拍摄透过树叶和树枝的面纱看到的人（也就是说，您想要使用透视技术！）。您希望人物处于焦点位置，而树叶则创建具有模糊效果的自然框架。如果你使用自动对焦，我几乎可以保证你的相机不会配合。你的镜头会来回搜索，直到将焦点放在一根树枝上，否则它会继续搜索，永远不会锁定拍摄对象。

这就是手动对焦可以发挥作用的地方。通过仔细调整对焦环，您可以准确地确定焦点所在的位置，从而拍摄出完美的照片！

或者您可能想尝试抽象的散景照片，其中整个图像除了失焦模糊之外什么都没有。你如何让相机的自动对焦功能聚焦在什么都没有的地方？你不能，但手动对焦可以让你掌控并确保你的焦点准确地落在你想要的地方。

底线：无论您是使用后焦来创建独特的模糊效果还是制作抽象图像，手动对焦都将为您提供所需的控制，使您的愿景变得栩栩如生。

广角摄影

使用广角镜头拍摄时，拍摄对象通常是以小比例显示的大型物体，例如树木、建筑物和其他无生命的物体。

在这种情况下，由于这些物体占据画面的一小部分，因此很难控制镜头的自动对焦；它可能会将焦点锁定在图像中不需要的区域。

我倾向于切换到手动对焦，尽管在某些相机上，您确实可以选择放大液晶显示屏上的预览并使用触摸屏仔细选择正确的对焦点。

全景摄影

拍摄全景图（通过在后期制作中将一组照片拼接在一起创建）时，整个镜头的一致性是关键。

这包括对焦一致性，即每个图像的对焦距离完全相同。否则，您将得到一个脱节的结果，并且您将无法让观众相信他们正在观看一张连续的照片。

这就是手动对焦派上用场的地方。您可以使用它来选择焦点并使镜头聚焦在同一位置，无论您旋转相机时场景如何变化。

超焦距摄影

无论您是拍摄连绵起伏的山丘还是熙熙攘攘的城市场景，在整个画面中实现完全清晰度都是非常理想的——它会增加镜头的深度，而且会让观看者欣赏每一个细节。

但捕捉从前景到背景都清晰的图像可能是一个挑战。第一步是选择一个窄光圈，例如 f/11，这有助于使更多场景清晰对焦，但这只是等式的一部分。如果没有完美放置的焦点，即使是窄光圈也无法保持整个场景清晰，特别是当您的构图包含前景元素时。

这就是超焦距发挥作用的地方。正是特定的焦点可以最大化您拍摄的景深。 （注意：您的相机没有内置超焦距计算器。在野外时，您可以使用经验法则，也可以找到一个可以为您进行计算的工具。）

一旦确定了超焦距所在的位置，就可以手动对焦该确切位置。自动对焦通常不会在这里发挥作用，因为它缺乏该技术所需的精度。手动对焦再次让您掌控一切，让您将镜头准确地设置在需要的位置，以捕捉令人惊叹的风景或城市景观的所有辉煌。

低对比度情况

自动对焦依赖于图像中暗色调和亮色调之间的对比度。对比度使自动对焦能够说：“嘿，这是我应该关注的主题。”

在低对比度的情况下，例如深色背景下的深色树木或雪景下的白色汽车，自动对焦可能会让您失败。对比度的缺乏会导致自动对焦系统连续搜索，这不仅令人烦恼而且效率低下。

这时您可能想切换到手动对焦。通过控制对焦环，您无需进行搜索即可获得所需的清晰度。只要记住当您转向不同的主题时切换回自动对焦，以便您准备好快速应对下一个摄影机会！

手动对焦与自动对焦：手动对焦什么时候不好？

手动对焦可能是摄影工具箱中的强大工具，但它并不总是最佳选择。

如果您正在处理移动的拍摄对象或快节奏的场景，手动对焦可能完全没有效果。您可能会尝试使用镜头，但没有时间来回移动对焦环、在液晶显示屏上检查焦点和/或重新拍摄照片，您可能会错过这一时刻。

因此，在体育摄影、野生动物摄影、鸟类摄影、事件摄影和汽车摄影等类型中，自动对焦通常是您的朋友。相机的自动对焦系统旨在快速锁定拍摄对象并使其保持清晰，因此在动作场景中，它通常是更好的选择。

当然，规则总有例外。如果您在夜间拍摄动物并且自动对焦无法锁定拍摄对象，则可以考虑手动对焦。但根据经验，在处理动作时坚持自动对焦。在这些情况下它更加可靠，并且可以让您免去因错过镜头而带来的挫败感！

摄影中的手动对焦：最后的话

手动对焦可能看起来令人畏惧，但现在您已经完成了本文，您知道它很简单 - 而且在正确的场景中它会非常有用。

所以练习手动对焦。即使你一开始很挣扎，你也会变得更好。你会很高兴你花时间去学习。

低光风景摄影给摄影师带来了独特的挑战。一方面，用更柔和、更微妙的光线照亮的风景可以拍出超越传统照片的神奇照片。另一方面，捕捉这些场景需要仔细的方法和对相机设置的敏锐理解。

但别担心！通过正确的指导，即使是初学者也可以在昏暗的风景场景中创作出令人惊叹的图像。在这篇文章中，我将解释：

  • 如何始终如一地进行低光曝光
  • 如何保持相机稳定以获得坚如磐石的图像
  • 如何利用光线创造美丽的长时间曝光
  • 如何选择完美的低光景观设置
  • 多得多！

因此，无论您打算在黄昏、黎明还是在黑暗的森林中拍摄，我们都可以直接开始拍摄。

低光风景摄影的最佳设置

每张图像都是独一无二的，但某些设置是低光照条件下拍摄的良好起点。随着时间的推移，您会形成自己的偏好，但以下是我在您首次进入该领域时的建议：

RAW文件格式

如果您已经进行风景摄影有一段时间了，您可能已经厌倦了听到这样的说法，但 RAW 文件会对您的照片产生如此大的影响。如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，则可以恢复丢失的细节，还可以对颜色和色调进行看起来自然的调整。

手动模式

我知道这看起来令人畏惧，但手动模式确实非常适合风景摄影，尤其是低光风景摄影。这就是为什么我强烈建议使用手动拍摄。它可以让您不断调整设置，还可以让您查明每次调整对图像的影响，以便您可以进行试验，直到获得良好的结果。

狭窄的光圈

一般来说，选择 f/8 或 f/16 等窄光圈是个好主意。这与标准的光线充足的风景光圈设置不会有太大变化——它会保持整个场景清晰，这通常是目标。也就是说，如果您进行天文摄影，您需要选择超宽光圈，例如 f/2.8，这样您就可以提高快门速度并防止星星模糊。

低ISO

将 ISO 设置为其基本值，通常为 ISO 100。这将最大限度地减少噪音，以确保编辑、共享和打印时获得最高质量的文件。

长快门速度

由于光圈和 ISO 通常相对固定，因此快门速度是您可以用来确保出色的整体曝光的变量。由于您将在有限的光线下工作，因此预计快门速度应在 1/30 秒到 60 秒之间。有时，您需要走得更久！

必备的低光风景成像装备

虽然您不需要急于花费数千美元购买新设备来拍摄弱光风景，但我确实鼓励您花一些时间考虑您拥有的设备以及进行一些升级是否可以改善您的图像。这是我的建议：

全画幅相机

最好的低光风景相机包含更大的传感器。 （为什么？平均而言，更大的传感器每个像素可以吸收更多的光线，从而在更高的 ISO 下获得更清晰的图像以及更广泛的动态范围功能。）因此，如果可以的话，请使用全画幅。

也就是说，如果您没有全画幅型号，也不必太担心。使用 APS-C 或三分之四相机仍然可以拍出好照片；只是在提高 ISO 或处理 HDR 场景时需要更加小心。

快速广角镜头

当然，大多数风景摄影师都会使用广角镜头进行拍摄。这样，他们就可以将整个华丽的场景融入到镜头中。

对于低光摄影，我建议您采用这种方法。广角定焦镜头可以提供出色的图像质量，价格便宜，并且可以提供令人兴奋的效果。广角变焦镜头，如 24-70 毫米、17-40 毫米或 16-35 毫米也很有帮助，但价格更高，因此购买前请仔细考虑。

还要确保检查镜头的最大光圈。对于标准的低光风景摄影，f/4 甚至 f/5.6 的最大光圈应该绝对没问题，但如果你想在夜间拍摄星星，f/2.8 是必备的。

坚固的三脚架

低光摄影提供的光线非常少（毫不奇怪！），因此快门速度很长。如果您不小心，您的图像最终会因相机抖动而损坏。这就是为什么三脚架绝对是百分百必不可少的。

如果您能负担得起，我会推荐相对较轻的碳纤维三脚架，但请确保不要在质量上吝啬。没有什么比买了一个摇摇晃晃的三脚架，拍摄了数百张柔和的图像，然后才意识到你应该一直购买一个好的产品更糟糕的了。

远程发布

即使使用三脚架拍摄长时间曝光的风景照片，按下快门按钮仍然可能导致相机抖动。

这就是远程快门释放派上用场的地方。它们让您无需触摸实际按钮即可触发快门。它们也相当便宜，特别是如果您愿意选择简单的版本。

您还可以选择使用相机的自拍功能，但如果您要拍摄对时间敏感的长时间曝光（例如海浪拍打海岸），则自拍功能会成为主要障碍。 Plus, using a remote release is far more convenient!

改善弱光风景照片的技巧

现在让我们深入研究一些真正提升低光图像水平的技术，首先：

1. 花一些时间寻找你的位置

低光风景摄影通常需要在接近黎明或黄昏时拍摄。在这些时候，能见度可能非常有限，您最不想看到的就是在黑暗中跌跌撞撞。因此，提前进行一些侦察是非常有必要的。

白天参观该地点，并四处走动以感受地形。寻找有趣的构图并想象光线如何影响场景。考虑一下太阳的位置，以及如果在您计划的拍摄期间太阳位于地平线以上，那么它的光线将如何在整个景观中产生阴影和高光。

考虑在白天进行一些测试，以帮助您直观地看到最终结果。另外，熟悉道路和周围环境，以便在天黑时可以安全导航。如果您计划在黄昏时分拍摄，请规划一条清晰且安全的路线返回您的汽车或基地位置。您绝对不想独自面对一堆重型（且昂贵）的设备！

请记住考虑可能会影响您所选地点的可达性的季节性和天气变化。安全至关重要，因此请务必确保在实际拍摄之前进行周密的考察旅行。

2. 在黄金时段和蓝色时段拍摄

虽然低光风景摄影提供了很多乐趣，但一天中的所有时间并非都是相同的 - 特别是在光线质量方面。

拍摄弱光场景的最佳时间从日落前半小时（ 黄金时段）开始，一直到太阳落入地平线后半小时左右（ 蓝色时段）。

Note: One common mistake many photographers make is leaving too soon after the sun sets.当然，黄金时刻是神奇的，但接下来的时刻也同样令人着迷。

日落之后或日出之前的蓝色时刻的微弱光线为创造力提供了独特的机会。颜色发生变化，景观呈现出新的维度。

因此，虽然光线变暗时你可能很想收拾行李，但请克制住这种冲动。要有耐心，停留一段时间，探索不断变化的光线。蓝色时刻可以为您的照片带来宁静和神秘的品质，这在一天中明亮的时段是很难实现的！

3. 手动设置白平衡

一些摄影师喜欢将白平衡保留为“自动”并在后期处理中进行调整，这是一种完全有效的拍摄方法 - 假设您使用的是 RAW。

然而，就我个人而言，我喜欢从一开始就获得正确的白平衡。这也意味着坐在电脑前的时间更少。

我建议手动设置白平衡（使用相机的自定义白平衡选项，在灰卡或中性表面上进行拍摄）。您也可以尝试拨入不同的值，然后进行测试拍摄，直到获得您喜欢的结果。

4.使用实时取景（如果可能的话，还有相机的电子快门）

每次使用数码单反相机拍照时，反光镜会弹起并且快门会移动 - 这两者都会导致模糊。 （在无反光镜相机上，当然没有反光镜，但快门仍然是一个问题。）

为了防止模糊，我建议使用实时显示进行拍摄。这会自动将镜子翻转起来，以便在拍照时不会妨碍它。

如果您的相机有电子快门，我还建议您使用电子快门进行拍摄。有些相机具有电子前帘快门，而其他相机则提供真正的电子快门；任何一种类型都可以。重点是消除快门造成的模糊，即快门震动。

5.不要害怕增加ISO

正如我上面强调的，低 ISO 通常最适合弱光风景，但有时您会想要提高 ISO。

具体来说，当您在近乎黑暗的环境中拍摄并且希望将快门速度保持在 30 秒左右以下时，高 ISO 非常有用。这样，您就可以防止天空中的星星变得模糊，并生成清晰的银河系图像。

如果您需要确定一定的快门速度（例如创意模糊效果）并且您正在努力获得正确的曝光，那么高 ISO 也很有帮助。

不过，切勿高于必要的水平。 ISO 越高，图像的噪点就越多。虽然现代全画幅相机可以处理大量噪点，但请尽可能降低噪点。

6. 注意不需要的运动模糊

我无法充分强调保持相机稳定以避免因相机抖动而导致模糊的重要性。但还有另一种类型的模糊可能会渗入您的图像并影响最终结果。

我说的是画面中元素的运动，例如吹动的小草或颤抖的花朵。如果您的快门速度超过几分之一秒，这些元素将开始丢失细节。

现在，运动模糊并不总是坏事。有时，它可以给您的图像带来空灵的效果。但剧烈移动的植被造成的强烈模糊可能会影响整个场景。你最终得到的不是宁静或戏剧性的风景，而是一片混乱的大杂烩，失去了细节。

那么，如果您遇到不想模糊的移动元素，该怎么办？有时，需要耐心等待风势平息。其他时候，最好在更有利的日子重新访问该位置。您还可以尝试提高 ISO 或扩大光圈以实现更快的快门速度，但每个设置调整也会以其他方式对您的图像产生负面影响。

7. 加入前景元素以增加比例

我已经讨论了很多关于低光风景拍摄中的设置和光线的问题，但构图也很重要。您可以从基础知识开始：三分法则、极简主义、负空间和引导线。

但我最好的建议是加入某种前景兴趣，比如一块岩石、一根圆木或一条河流。然后让它吸引观众的眼球并将他们带入画面中。

事实上，风景摄影师喜欢前景元素，尤其是当它们与广角镜头结合使用时。但也要确保你有一个有趣的背景元素；前景技术很棒，但前提是背景元素能为观看者的眼睛提供休息的地方。

8. 进行大量测试拍摄（并使用直方图检查曝光）

低光风景摄影可能是不可预测的，因此我强烈建议您拍摄尽可能多的测试照片，仔细检查您拍摄的图像，并在拍摄时快速但频繁地检查直方图。

（事实上​​，如果您使用无反光镜拍摄，您甚至可以实时看到直方图；这样，您甚至不需要摆弄曝光测试镜头！）

但请记住：直方图是一个指南，而不是国王。您可能会注意到图表底部偶尔会出现一些音调，这没关系。毕竟，低光场景有时应该看起来很暗。 And you might notice the occasional tones pressing up against the top end of the graph, which is also okay;例如，城市的灯光会熄灭，这通常看起来非常酷，尤其是在具有星爆效果时。

因此，请仔细注意您的直方图，并使用它来确保您已经完成了低光拍摄。 But don't obsess if the histogram doesn't show you a “perfect” curve.

9. 拍摄美丽的长曝光图像

我在整篇文章中都谈到了在弱光条件下使用长时间曝光的重要性。但现在让我们更深入地探讨一下如何利用这项技术来发挥自己的优势。

长时间曝光技术可以真正提升您的图像质量。想象一下流动的水变得丝滑，或者快速移动的云像棉花糖一样在天空中伸展。这些效果是通过提高快门速度来实现的，它们可以为您的照片增添令人惊叹的质量。

关键是要进行实验并找到完美的快门速度。不同的速度可以添加或删除移动元素的纹理。 Perhaps a 2s exposure renders a river too smooth, while a 1/10s exposure gives it just the right amount of motion. Don't be afraid to try different settings until you achieve the look you're after.

Also, consider the specific elements that will be affected by the long exposure and adjust your composition accordingly. Incorporating elements like streaking clouds can add dynamism and visual interest.

Taking the time to master long exposures in low light can open up a world of creative possibilities. With patience, practice, and a willingness to experiment, you'll find yourself capturing images that stand out from the crowd.

10. Bracket your exposures for maximum detail

Landscape photographers, including low-light landscape photographers, are faced with a unique problem:

Capturing tonal detail throughout a scene, even when the scene features a bright sky and a dark foreground, or bright city lights and dark buildings.

In other words, landscape photographers must learn to balance exposures so as to retain maximum detail. A histogram is ultra-helpful, as I mentioned in the last section – but what if you're not sure whether you got the result you wanted, even with the histogram? And even more concerning: What if a good result is impossible, simply because the difference because the brightest brights and the darkest darks in your photos are too significant?

That's where exposure bracketing comes in. It's a simple technique, but it's a huge deal for the committed landscape photographer. Here's how it works:

  1. Take a shot with a middle exposure value.
  2. Adjust your settings (generally the shutter speed) to slightly underexpose the scene, then take a shot.
  3. Adjust your settings (again, generally the shutter speed) to slightly overexpose the scene, then take a shot.

To some extent, you're creating backups, so that if you get the exposure slightly wrong, you still have a well-exposed image to fall back on. However, exposure bracketing can do more than that; you can actually blend several bracketed images together in Lightroom or Photoshop, taking the most detail from different parts of the images, so that the underexposed image contributes a beautiful sky, while the overexposed image contributes rich shadows. That way, you get the best of both worlds (and a stunning final result). Make sense?

And by the way: You can bracket as broadly as you like. Three bracketed images are pretty common (often with a margin of two stops), but you can also capture five, seven, nine, or more bracketed shots!

Hopefully, you now feel much more confident – and you know exactly how to capture low-light landscape shots like a pro.

So head out into the field and practice (though make sure you bring a trusty tripod and a remote release along!).

Lighting can make or break a portrait. In my experience, it's often what turns an ordinary snapshot into a professional-looking image. Clamshell lighting is a technique that's simple yet powerful, and it can take your photography to the next level.

But what is clamshell lighting? And how can you master clamshell lighting setups for stunning results?

In this article, I explain the ins and outs of this simple – yet incredibly powerful – two-light portrait setup. From experimenting with different modifiers to playing with light positions and beyond, I'll explore all the details to help you master this wonderful lighting technique. By the time you're finished reading, you'll know how to create clamshell-lit portraits like a pro (no matter your lighting gear!).

So if you're ready to become a clamshell portrait master, then let's dive right in, starting with the basics:

What is clamshell lighting?

Clamshell lighting is a simple, two-light configuration: You place both lights facing your subject at a 45-degree angle, one angled up, one angled down. Note that your key light (ie, your primary, brighter light) should point 45 degrees downward, while your fill light should point 45 degrees upward. Your camera should sit between the two lights, facing your subject.

When viewed from the side, the two lights resemble an open clamshell (imagination may be required!):

A clamshell setup provides beautiful, soft light with faint shadows and glorious catchlights. Clamshell lighting works well on pretty much everyone; I'd say that it's flattering for men and women of all ages, so it's a great setup to have in your back pocket.

Note that clamshell lighting is just like butterfly lighting , except that you add the fill light below the subject (which eliminates any heavy shadows caused by the key light). So if you're already doing a butterfly setup, you can always add in a clamshell look at the end for some variation!

How to create a clamshell lighting setup: step-by-step process


Creating a clamshell lighting setup is simple, and as long as you have two working lights, you're practically guaranteed to pull it off. Here's what you do:

Step 1: Select your lights and modifiers

Clamshell lighting requires two light sources, and these can be strobes or continuous, modified or unmodified.

Personally, I'd recommend you use modifiers – these will help soften the light for a more flattering effect – and grabbing a pair of similarly sized softboxes is a great starting point.

That said, if you don't have modifiers or you prefer a harder look, then work with an unmodified light! If you really embrace the effect and sculpt it as needed, you may get a great result. Plus, it's your photoshoot!

Step 2: Position your key light

Grab your key light (ie, your main light source). The goal is to place it in front of your subject and slightly above; angle it down so it points directly at the subject's nose.

If you want a softer effect that features fast light falloff, bring the light in close to the subject's face. If you want a harder effect that lights the subject more broadly, move the light farther away.

Next, meter for your desired aperture (we'll use a hypothetical f/11) and take a test shot.

If everything is set up correctly, you should produce a decently lit image with deep shadows under your subject's nose and chin. (If the image is too dim, feel free to brighten your light, and if the image is overexposed, do the reverse.)

Step 3: Add your fill light

Now it's time to add in the second light; take your fill light and place it directly underneath your key light, pointed upward toward your subject at 45 degrees.

Adjust the light's brightness until it sits two stops below the key light. (If you wanted to shoot at f/11, you could meter your fill light for an f/5.6 result.) Then take a second test shot.

If the effect is too strong and your fill light is obliterating the shadows, turn down the light power. If the light isn't doing enough, turn it up. The main thing to look out for is the fill light overpowering the key light, as that would result in a very unflattering image that's lit from below.

Step 4: Capture your clamshell image!

At this point, you should have two lights sharing the same vertical space, and the light on top should be roughly two stops brighter than the light on the bottom.

Stand behind the lights and shoot through the gap. Note: If there isn't much of a gap to work with, raise and/or lower both of your lights until you have enough room to shoot in the middle. To be safe, you may want to take another meter reading.

Of course, once you've grabbed a shot or two, check your camera's LCD for exposure issues and other concerns. And if you have the capability, I recommend tethering your camera to your laptop; that way, you can review your images instantly on the big screen.

And that's all there is to it! Clamshell lighting is really easy to do, and with a bit of practice, you'll be able to get the two-light setup running in a couple of minutes.

Clamshell vs butterfly lighting

Butterfly lighting and clamshell lighting are often discussed together, but they're two very distinct lighting patterns.

A basic butterfly lighting setup uses just one light, positioned above and angled down toward the subject. Since there's no fill light, the shadows on the nose and chin remain heavy, giving more dramatic and intense results. It's an effect that can be particularly well-suited for fashion photography.

Now, let's compare this to clamshell lighting. Clamshell lighting involves placing a second light below the subject, softening the shadows. This produces a gentler, more soothing effect, so it's often seen in conventional headshot photography or applications with far less drama.

Pro tip: If you're uncertain about the final look you want, you can always start with butterfly lighting. Experiment with the shadows and angles, then simply add a fill light to achieve the clamshell look if you desire something softer. This way, you can play around with two different lighting styles with very little effort. It's a convenient and creative approach to portrait lighting.

Clamshell vs Rembrandt lighting

Another classic lighting technique to consider? Rembrandt lighting. The Rembrandt pattern involves placing a light off to the side of the subject – often around 45 degrees – to create a clear triangle of light on the subject's cheek.

Because it covers so much of the face in shadows, Rembrandt lighting is known for its dark and moody qualities. It's a favorite among those seeking a dramatic, theatrical style in their images.

So how does clamshell lighting stack up against Rembrandt? Clamshell lighting is the better choice if you want a more cheerful, detailed shot. By positioning lights both above and below your subject, you can illuminate the face more evenly and reduce harsh shadows. This brings out more of the facial details and gives the image a livelier, more approachable feeling.

In short, if drama and moodiness are your goals, Rembrandt lighting may be the way to go. But for a more uplifting and detailed portrait, clamshell lighting fits the bill. Understanding the nuances of these lighting techniques will allow you to choose the right style for each unique portrait session. Experiment with both, and see what you think!

Clamshell photography setup: a few quick tips

You know how to capture a basic clamshell image. But how can you take your shots even further? Here are a few of my top tips to help you out:

1. Experiment with different modifiers

When you're first starting out with clamshell lighting, softboxes can be your best friends. They provide a gentle touch that's perfect for beginners. But as you get more comfortable, you might find yourself wanting to explore other options. This is an excellent idea .

Have a pair of strip boxes you want to use? Go for it. Want to use a beauty dish as your key light and an umbrella as fill? Sure. How about a snoot and a small softbox?绝对地。 Use what you have at hand. Pretty soon, you'll be able to improvise like a pro.

Beauty dishes, for instance, create a harder look that can add drama to a portrait. Their focused light can accentuate textures and details. On the other hand, umbrellas can really soften up the shadows. By throwing around a lot of light, they make everything feel more diffused and ethereal.

By testing out different modifiers, you'll learn how they affect your images. So don't be afraid to try something new. Just remember to keep the essence of clamshell lighting in mind: that beautiful, flattering glow that makes portraits shine.

2. Try repositioning your lights

Light position matters in clamshell lighting, and even an adjustment of a few inches can dramatically change the final image.

Move the lights closer to your subject, and the shadows will soften and become more gradated for a gentle and delicate look.

Move the lights farther from your subject, and the shadows will harden and become sharper. This can add a sense of depth and drama to the image.

But it's not just about distance. You can move your key light higher to create longer shadows or lower to create shorter shadows. You can do the same with the fill light.

Just be cautious not to go overboard. The 45-degree positions that I discussed in my initial step-by-step section are designed to look flattering. Playing with the positioning is great, but don't lose sight of your original goals!

3. Add more lights

Once you've set up your clamshell lighting just right, you might think you're done. But there's more you can do to enhance the scene and create striking images.

For instance, you can add rim lights behind your subject, either on one side or both, to create a delicate sliver of light around the head. This effect will help your subject pop off the background and make the image more dynamic.

A hair light can add depth to your photograph. Positioned above and behind the subject, it shines subtly on the hair to separate it from the background.

Don't hesitate to experiment with background lights, as well. Placing a light behind the subject (that's pointed at the backdrop) can create a beautiful cone of light that adds extra depth. It's how many photographers combine a well-lit subject with a well-lit background!

Bottom line: By adding these additional lights, you give yourself more creative freedom and open up a world of possibilities in your clamshell lighting setups.

4. Convert to black and white

Clamshell lighting produces wonderful images that can look stunning in both color and black and white. Converting your shot to black and white will emphasize the interplay of shadows and highlights while potentially adding a layer of three-dimensionality to the photo.

If you shoot in RAW, and I highly recommend you do, you have the flexibility to photograph using your camera's Monochrome mode and still convert back to color if needed. Or you can start in color and convert to black and white later on.

The black-and-white conversion can make the features of the face stand out in a unique way. It might bring out textures, emphasize contrasts, or even create a mood that color doesn't capture. Experimenting with this conversion allows you to explore a range of visual expressions within a single lighting setup, which is always a good idea!

5. Watch the catchlights

Catchlight is that magical spot of light in the subject's eyes, one that's created by a reflection from the light source. It brings life to the eyes; without a catchlight, the eyes – and the entire portrait – can appear flat and lifeless.

Therefore, it's important that you always make sure your clamshell photos include catchlights! If a catchlight isn't present, you may need to ask your subject to angle their head, or you may need to make slight adjustments to your lights. Make sure to review each test shot on your camera's LCD to ensure that the catchlight is just as you want it.

Note that with clamshell lighting, since it involves two lights rather than one, you might notice a double catchlight. This is a feature some photographers love, while others are less enthusiastic.

If you're not a fan of the bottom catchlight, don't fret! It can always be cloned out during post-processing.

Clamshell lighting examples

Now let's take a look at some clamshell examples. You can use them as inspiration, though don't limit yourself – these are just a handful of the many clamshell setups you can create!

Clamshell lighting: final words

If you've made it this far, you should understand the power of a basic clamshell lighting setup.

Of course, you can always take your clamshell setups to the next level with additional lights and modifiers, but even the basics are guaranteed to get good results.

So head into your studio and try some clamshell lighting out for yourself!
